description_long: Assessment of the sustainability of construction processes and materials used, including responsible sourcing, waste minimization during construction, use of recycled/reused materials, and application of circular economy principles.
sub_questions: What measures are proposed to minimize waste during the construction process (e.g., off-site manufacturing, material optimization)?
What targets are set for the diversion of construction waste from landfill (e.g., percentage recycled/reused)?
Are sustainably or responsibly sourced materials being specified (e.g., FSC/PEFC timber, BES 6001 certified products)?
Is there a commitment to using materials with high recycled content or reused materials?
How are circular economy principles being applied to material selection and end-of-life considerations?
What is the environmental impact of the primary construction materials chosen (e.g., embodied carbon, resource depletion)?
Are there any specific commitments regarding local sourcing of materials?
typical_positive_impacts: High levels of construction waste diverted from landfill.
Significant use of responsibly sourced, recycled, or reused materials.
Demonstrable application of circular economy principles.
Reduced environmental impact from material choices.
Achieves high ratings in material sections of environmental assessments (e.g., BREEAM).
typical_negative_impacts: Low rates of construction waste recycling.
Heavy reliance on virgin materials with high environmental impact.
Little or no consideration of responsible sourcing or circular economy.
Failure to implement an effective Site Waste Management Plan.
common_mitigation_measures: Development and implementation of a robust Site Waste Management Plan (SWMP).
Setting targets for waste reduction and recycling.
Specification of materials with recognized responsible sourcing certifications.
Designing for deconstruction and material reuse at end-of-life.
Use of off-site construction methods to reduce waste and improve quality.
Supplier engagement to encourage sustainable material options and take-back schemes.
